column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1. Introduction
#Text=Microfluidic devices have obtained global relevance since their initial application in miniaturized separation and chromatographic instrumentation .
#Text=More recently , micro-total-analysis systems ( µTAS ) , have been applied to chemical analysis and environmental monitoring .
#Text=The small , low-cost , power efficient nature of microfluidic analysis platforms have even been used for in situ ocean nutrient sensors in recent years .
#Text=Their potential to do automated and low-volume measurements at high pressures makes them amenable for sensor deployment in deep ocean environments .
#Text=However , reliable fluid handling remains a core development area in establishing higher levels of integration on microfluidic devices .
#Text=This is typically accomplished with specialized micro-valves and micro-pumps .
#Text=Microfabricated valves fall into one of two categories : Active or passive .
#Text=Active valves require external actuation and often rely on off-chip support systems .
#Text=A typical active membrane valve uses induced fluid pressure to actuate a movable diaphragm to seal a channel .
#Text=Generating and controlling pressure for these on-chip active valves require a substantial amount of energy and external equipment that limit the ability to miniaturize .
#Text=Complex in situ lab-on-chip systems employ multiple pneumatic or hydraulic actuators driven by off-chip solenoids .
#Text=In the works by Ogilvie et al. and Beaton et al. , completely automated lab-on-chip nutrient sensors contained 10 – 15 actuators .

#Text=The solenoids contributed to a significant power draw during operation for fluid routing and handling , over 10 Watts , equating to 100 s if not 1000 s of Joules of energy per sample measurement .
#Text=Using this much energy per sample limits the number of measurements possible per deployment with current battery capacities on small autonomous underwater vehicles and drifting floats .
#Text=Incorporating rugged passive valves can reduce the energy demand for fluid handling on microfluidic devices .

#Text=Passive valves require no external power or interface and most often use simple mechanical biases , like an elastomeric membrane , or some other physical property to restrict fluid flow in one direction .
#Text=The Tesla valve , for example , uses an in-channel geometric pattern to increase fluidic resistance in one direction and not the other .
#Text=Passive valves can also be made by exploiting capillary pressure differences in microchannels , or by using an air bladder to create a capillary stop-valve .
#Text=Other types of valves include using comb-like structures or centrifugal elastic valves .
#Text=Flap valves are perhaps the most common and use a thin membrane that seals against a rigid body in one direction , and have freedom to deflect in the other .
#Text=Although flap valves generally seal well against reverse flow , they are still subject to leakage at low flow rates and do not have a strong seal in an unbiased state .
#Text=Furthermore , such membrane valves are usually made up of at least two distinct materials , requiring unique bonding procedures between layers .

#Text=This introduces extra manufacturing equipment and methods , such as UV exposure/oxygen plasma/chemical surface modifications and are prone to sealing failures if stringent quality controls are not implemented .
#Text=Alternatively , a few researchers have implemented ball and cage valves based on the Starr – Edwards valve used in heart surgery .
#Text=When forward flow is applied , the ball is dislodged from a seat and retained by the cage .
#Text=In reverse flow , the ball is pushed into the seat , creating a seal .
#Text=However , like flap valves , ball valves show appreciable leakage , on the order of 100 µL min−1 when a reverse pressure of 25 kPa is applied .
#Text=Backflow is unacceptable and must me be minimized on any in situ marine sensor , as reagent cross-contamination reduces the integrity and accuracy of the measurements .
#Text=Many microfluidic applications use magnetic fields to implement on-chip actuation without direct physical coupling .
#Text=Micro-magnetofluids , for example , can be manipulated with an external magnetic field to perform on-chip mixing , pumping , or even droplet formation .
#Text=Yamahata et al. and Shen et al. have explored the use of permanent magnets encased in a deformable membrane to act as a piston for a solenoid-based micropump .
#Text=The reported systems use oscillating magnetic fields to drive an on-chip piston with two ball-style check valves to pump fluid .
#Text=Other groups in the biomedical field have researched magnetic hydrogels to create magnetically actuated microvalves .
#Text=These systems , however , are intended for use in benchtop applications and are not likely to withstand extreme pressure environments .
#Text=Furthermore , the valves require more than 3 s to fully seal , which exceeds the activation time requirement for many applications .
#Text=Single use drug delivery systems have used permanent magnets as external valve actuators but are targeted for limited and disposable applications .
#Text=Magnetorheological fluids can be actuated using a permanent magnet to seal a microchannel .
#Text=These innovative valves , however , are made with an intermediary PDMS layer , and partially seal 80 – 90 % of the channel at extremely low flow rates ( <0.1 µL min−1 ) .
#Text=Other common valve designs use magnetized polymers to create magnetically actuated membrane valves .
#Text=Valves of this sort , however , require the fabrication and bonding of specialized polymers .
#Text=Many of the reported magnetic valves in the literature , as listed above , are activated with external linear translation stages or with energy intensive electronic systems .
#Text=Passively biased magnetic valves are much less common but have potential for use in power restricted applications .
